Author: mkult1a
Content:
https://github.com/mkeras/Arduino-PMC-Clock

I made a simple class (with help from chatGPT) for the Arduino Portenta Machine Control. I plan to modify/test it to work on the Opta as well, but I am focused on building a complete sparkplug 3 node first. It's a simple way to get unix timestamps in milliseconds, automatically synchronized with an NTP server and the RTC of the PMC.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Apologies if this isn't the best place for this question - but for my automation / electrical junkies, I've been assigned a task to DfM our electronic board's wiring. We have about 50 discrete wires that are just cumbersome to wire individually, error-prone, consumes space, and actually makes our product look kinda cheap (think like a board with about 50 wires coming out of it, with no duct etc.). I've got some ideas....but my mgmt. also wants to evaluate board re-designs, daughter boards, M-F connectors etc.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: The process goal is to connectorize the board - so the assembler just connects pre-terminated cables. With this in mind, does anyone have resources on how to systematically approach this kind of a problem? Thank you

Author: brianpribe
Content:
I do a lot of wiring for industrial panels. I would look at Phoenix Contact for all of the various products they have for PCBs. 

Consolidate, Integrate, Eliminate.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Thats a great way to put it....our base connectors are 1952801

Author: sammysevens777
Content: And right now we have 50 sets of them with a 1952283. The thought is unless we redesign the PCB...we remove the 1952283 and then use some kind of pass through connector to a daughter board....and connectorize from there....

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Not a single connector, we have mix of DI/DO, AI/AO, safety I/O, 24V/12V, and some serial too

Author: brianpribe
Content: So for this product, where is it supposed to live? In a control enclosure? In an office? On the plant floor?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Inside of a stationary cabinet (inspection machine).

Author: brianpribe
Content: So IP20. Aside from having the CAN and serial terminals be ports instead, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a good way to make it more plug n play

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Yeah the cabinet is sealed and washdown (IP69K). 

Right now they are all individual wires...wouldnt converting end into poke yoke connectors be a good idea? At least for us....we have a lot of wiring isues....

Author: brianpribe
Content: I‚Äôm still not 100% on how the PCB is being used. Are you connecting multiple PCBs together? Or is the PCB a final product and you are having to wire a bunch of devices to it?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Yes exactly (the latter). The board uses a PIC microcontroller and has electronics to control signals interfaced by 1952801

Author: brianpribe
Content: Your PCB isn‚Äôt the problem, it‚Äôs your wiring process and documentation.

Author: brianpribe
Content: You can wire panels like this in one go with the right processes and documentation (practice too).

Author: nickn5549
Content: Yes, but the PCBs are making your life much, much easier when complexity grows - I'll send some pics from some of our machines - once I'm back to work

Author: brianpribe
Content: 100%. Wiring is expensive. Each wire installed is $2.00 (in the panel only). You can imagine how pricey it gets for large projects. M12 cables, IO blocks, Ethernet, and terminal systems are a godsend for large systems.

Author: nickn5549
Content: We are more in PCBA manufacturing, but any time when we have cabinets to build we do DFA ( Design for Assembly) and normally we suggest to 'connectorize' and approach it something like this -- identify the wires that need to be replaced, determine the type an numer of connectors needed, design the PCB(s) to accomodate these connectors, build the 'standardised' cables, test your design, refine the design, document the design, get approval if needed. For each PCB we do DFM (Design for Manufacturability) to make sure that are easy to build - PCB Fab and PCB Assy.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I do my best to stay away from making custom cables. They f*cking suck. For one-off machines (which I mostly do), I really try to keep my schematics utilizing standard cables (M12). Not just that, but if you have to replace that cable it's even more of a headache. Had a customer once request a custom cable, I asked 10 questions to get all of the information I need. They just sent over a 3 different documents that "should answer all of my questions". I ended up with 3 different part numbers for one end of the cable....

Author: brianpribe
Content: Oh and no part numbers for the other end.

Author: nickn5549
Content: for one-offs is not worthed to do all these steps...when you talk volumes..then is another story. I'm the same for my custom designs (my other hat than EMS) - wires are the way until volumes go up...

Author: sammysevens777
Content: This sounds fantastic....are there any templates i could use to follow this orocess along?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: If only our cabinet was designed thoughtfully like this one. There are literally no wire ducts and for some reason components are oriented vertically and horizontally. Furthermore, the panel is affixed to the machine, so our poor assemblers have to sit in the same spot behind the machine for days....it should have been removable and a subassembly.....its the design really....and i have several ideas, but not sure if they'll get traction as current focus is on simplifying connections to current board

Author: nickn5549
Content: Yes, many times people don't see passed their nose...and I have sometimes troubles making the argument that robust DFA upfront saves you heaps in mass production..

Author: nickn5549
Content: Templates? I have to ask my engineers. For DFA we don't have software for it, it is manually done based on the steps listed before. For DFM, PCBA level, we use the Valor MSS DFM module to do it automatically.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: What housing material would you recommend for a rigged environmental chamber? Cement boards seem like a good idea....

Author: nickn5549
Content: We just got a new project where we have to apply the DFA 'templates' - I'll come back with details as we progress through

Author: .kwinn
Content: I have a question: I have setup a websocket server using socket.io on nodejs. How do I send messages to that server from an arduino with esp8266 for wifi? which library am I supposed to use for this?

Author: .kwinn
Content: it's an odd case though I don't have the arduino with me. I need to get started on the code so I can finish it tomorrow it school (where the arduino is) so it's hard to test things.

Author: .kwinn
Content: I've seen an example using ArduinoWebsockets but it seems like there is no topic sent? How do I handle this in socket.io?

Author: .kwinn
Content: is there maybe a way to simulate an arduino with network capabilities for exactly this?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Kwinn, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Websockets don't dictate any particular type of payload (e.g. topics, data formats, etc).  You'll connect to a specific endpoint on the websocket server, and then formulate and send some type of payload (JSON, text, binary, XML, etc).  Look at the code on your socket.io server to see what it is expecting.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: https://www.makeuseof.com/arduino-simulators-electronics-projects/

Author: .kwinn
.kwinn
Content: ty I'll try those

Author: rickbullotta
Content: No.  "message" is the event that is being handled.  "data" is the payload.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I have no idea what you're talking about with "topic".

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There's no such concept with websockets alone.

Author: .kwinn
Content: I'm really lost so I'll try to rephrase

Author: .kwinn
Content: `"message"` is the name of my event. my socket server listens to anything incoming with this event right? how do I make it so the arduino sends data that is tagged with the event `"message"`

Author: .kwinn
rickbullotta
Content: oh, jeez.  that's what you get for trusting ChatGPT. üòâ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Post your full server side code/Node.js code

Author: .kwinn
Content: it's literally just this. it just forwards the stuff right away to my frontend where I am going to do stuff with it

Author: .kwinn
Content:
https://github.com/Links2004/arduinoWebSockets/blob/master/examples/esp8266/WebSocketClientSocketIO/WebSocketClientSocketIO.ino
I'm gonna try this tomorrow at school with some edits

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
I think you're trying to mix a generic websocket client with a socket.io server.  That probably won't work.  See this info:

https://ably.com/topic/socketio-vs-websocket#:~:text=Socket.IO%20is%20not%20compatible,a%20plain%20WebSocket%20server%20either.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
You will likely have better luck using ws on the server:

https://www.npmjs.com/package/ws

Author: .kwinn
Content: Yee that's what I figured out at some point that's why I had confusions in first place. But the library this example is from seems to have socket io supporf

Author: .kwinn
Content: If the library won't work out I'll try to use ws

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Take a look at this code example - it uses a specific JSON format that includes the event name:

https://github.com/Links2004/arduinoWebSockets/blob/master/examples/esp8266/WebSocketClientSocketIO/WebSocketClientSocketIO.ino

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content:
Just like the Arduino Opta, I was able to connect to WiFi and publish to an MQTT broker with the Arduinio XIAO ESP32 C3 similar to@Walker Reynolds in the Arduino Opta WiFI Youtube video.




https://www.youtube.com/live/QefnmQWsfL4

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content:
I used Perplexity.ai since it does not require a login. I'm using this for a high school summer camp, so no login makes things easier. Here is the prompt: 
For the Seeed Studio XIAO ESP32C3, create an Arduino program to connect to WiFi using eet124 as the SSID and buttercup as the password. Please reference the documentation at https://wiki.seeedstudio.com/XIAO_ESP32C3_Getting_Started/ Also connect to an MQTT broker located at tcp://45.76.236.64:1883 with no authentication needed. Publish the IP address of the ESP32 to the topic ESP32/IPAddress
modify this program to include an overall summary in comments at the top and inline comments for each step
modify this program to publish every five seconds. Also include wifi signal strength

Author: dylan_iiot
Content:
Thanks a mil. Im super new to the micro controller game. I'm looking to develop a product that will control remote water valves, and have multiple methods of connecting to the internet to cater for what may or may not be available at all the different locations. So the essentially the controller/product must be able to:
- control a DC motor (like "Planetary DC Gear Motor 25mm - 5RPM 12V") for rotating a valve
- control a 230Vac 1200W irrigation water pump
- have wifi, gsm and gps comms
So far I have this list of components recommended to me:
- ESP32-C3-MINI-1: ESP32-based microcontroller with integrated WiFi, GSM, and GPS capabilities.
- Planetary DC Gear Motor 25mm - 5RPM 12V: The motor for controlling the valve position.
- L298N Dual H-Bridge Motor Driver: Motor driver module for controlling the DC gear motor.
- Power supply: Suitable for providing power to the motor and motor driver module.
- 4x4 Keypad: Matrix keypad for user input to locally control the connect valve position.
- Relay output board: Compatible with the current rating of the pump motor.
- GSM Antenna: Suitable GSM antenna for cellular connectivity.
- GPS Antenna: Suitable GPS antenna for GPS positioning.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You can get a lot of that here - plus you get the software backend and device management.  It‚Äôll also work with Losant if you want a high level tool for apps.  https://store.particle.io

Author: cdrogemuller
Content:
Hi All - Has anyone had any luck getting MQTT working on the Arduino Opta using a sketch inside the PLC IDE specifically?
When using the standard IDE to create sketches that publish values to a broker using the PubSubClient library I have no issues however when those same sketches are downloaded using the PLC IDE the sketches appear to run however no values are published to the broker. 
From some googling I have found the following posts with similar issues and a response from an arduino member that MQTT and IOT cloud is currently not supported by the PLC IDE:
https://forum.arduino.cc/t/plc-program-mqtt-client-as-sketch/1104991/4
https://forum.arduino.cc/t/plc-ide-pubsub-sketch/1113956
Looking to hear if anyone has had any luck with this perhaps with another library.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: I've been using the pubsub library from Arduino to publish to an  MQTT broker with the ESP32c3. I used www.perplexity.ai to create a program to generate OEE data publishing topics according to ISA-95 Part 2. This image is from the Perspective Custom Dashboard project from the Ignition forum viewing the subscribed tags from the MQTT broker. Using this to teach the UNS architecture to my classes at Penn College.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: For those in Mentorship or Mastermind, I'm using the class EMQx broker. I'm going keep this powered on so it will continually produce data. You can find it in the ISA95 topic.

Author: mkult1a
Content:
Hopefully this is the right channel,
https://hub.docker.com/r/mkult1a/gpt-agent
I haven't looked to see if it's already been done, but I have started developing a simple docker container who's purpose is to consume events on a given MQTT Topic, and manipulate the incoming data via the chatGPT API and a given Prompt and Model, and publish the results to a given Topic.
The functionality is basic right now, but is suitable for testing and development of different prompts, etc., and the model and prompt can be changed via MQTT or environment variables.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Interesting

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Well that didn't take long.  I was wondering when someone would do something like this.  I was thinking it last week when i was working on my MQTT to neo app.  Curious on a couple of things.  I suspect it's not exactly snappy.   What's a complete roundtrip look like?   Do you get repeatable responses for the same payload and prompt?  I would expect not but may be wrong.   What have you tried to translate?  Thanks for sharing.  May take it for a spin and see myself.  you may want to post this in the #unified-namespace

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Makes more sense to generate code to do the transform than to use the API to do it. Could be slow and expensive.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: That's where i was headding in my thoughts.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Actually tried to build my own translator backend in node.js this weekend

Author: rickbullotta
Content: With a dynamic language like JavaScript you can always use something like eval with a custom context - that way you can change the algos on the fly.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I was going the harder way (i think) and passing it into a pyhon sandbox. Likely due to my bias toward python but working on moving that bias.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Security weenies hate eval() anyway.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: that's because they get burnt all the time. just end up with burnt weenies

Author: mkult1a
Content: Indeed it is not very snappy, although it depends on the model and prompt. My testing has been very limited so far, but for about 300 tokens total, it's taking about 2 or 3 seconds. I haven't tested for repeatability, but I was looking through the documentation, there are parameters (temperature, top_p, https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/completions/create#completions-create-temperature) I should add to the config for fine tuning repeatability. I will update the image and repost it into the uns channel. I'm also thinking about making the container a sparkplug node, so that it could be used/controlled with ignition.

I've got to bite the bullet and jump into learning CV, there's just so much more data available vs a simple sensor like a load cell. The load cell approach I'll still use for things like bolts and screws,  and anything else where vision can't see everything.

Author: mkult1a
Content:
Just finished an Arduino/microcontroller library for running as a sparkplug edge node. It's decoupled from any mqtt library for maximum compatibility (its all stdlib C). The API functions allow simple integration into an arduino sketch, and is designed to be easily used with virtually any other mqtt library. I have tested the example to be working on the arduino r4 wifi and the giga r1 (it just prints topic/payload to serial). This weekend I plan to add a complete example demonstrating pairing it with an mqtt client and actually connecting to a broker. Should appear in the  Arduino library shortly.

https://github.com/mkeras/EmbeddedSparkplugNode

Author: jramirez3
Content: Don't know if this is the correct place for this but I'm using Ignition maker edition at home and also using OpenHab to connect to alot of home automated devices. I want to transmiter the data from the OpenHab system via MQTT to the Ignition MQTT Broker. I am struggling getting the values to publish correct. I'm getting the connection from OpenHab to Ignition and in the logs I see the connection and the subscription start but tags never show up on the MQTT Engine tag provider. Any suggestions?

Author: donpancoe
Content: I'm still getting up to speed on this myself, but my understanding is that Ignition - by default - is looking for MQTT messages in the Sparkplug B / Protobuf format. OpenHAB is probably transmitting plain JSON over MQTT. I've read that you can still read these messages by creating a "custom namespace" in Ignition, but I will have to refer you to either the #ignition channel in this forum or the Inductive Automation forums for more specific details on that.

Author: jramirez3
Content: Ya I'm still learning OpenHab so that is more than likely the case. I guess I have to dig more into the custom namespaces in Ignition. I never had to do that because in my job we only use devices that use Sparkplug.

Author: aimane_00991
Content:
Hi everyone,
I'm working on understanding an industrial manufacturing machine, and I've come across an orange component that I believe is a sensor. Here are the details:
The component (there are 3 in image) is orange in color.
It's attached to the machine in a way that suggests it's monitoring or measuring something.
I suspect it might be a sensor, but I'm not sure what type or what its specific function might be.
Questions:
Can anyone help me identify what type of sensor this might be?
What is the typical use of an orange sensor in an industrial manufacturing setup?
Any insights or resources you could provide would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: No idea of an standard on the sensor color, but they seem like optical sensor, they sense when an object cross the light array in front of them

Author: aimane_00991
Content:
in reality, it is an Automatic Screw Capper:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o4KM3pgq1bI&ab_channel=CDAFrance
but why sensors are placed in that way ??

Author: brianpribe
Content: Look at 1:09. The sensors are mounted on the clamp's though-holes. Rather than making a new fixture plate, they just mounted it where a hole was available.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The orange sensor on the right, looks to be the a reflection sensor used to determine if there is a pail present or not. you can see the light at the end of the device turn on and off, when there is an object( pail) infront of them.
That rightmost sensor when it detects a pail triggers the actuated arm that holds the pail in place while it is being capped.
given how the other two are places on the left, I would guess they are used to maintain, the supply of pails , and take action if there are too many or too few. they seam to be pointed at the front and end of the pail queue.

the sensors seam to be Leuze on their side so maybe they are one of theses https://www.leuze.com/en-in/products/switching-sensors/optical-sensors/retro-reflective-photoelectric-sensors.

I would have expected red for Leuze, but it does really look like a PRK3C.T3/PT-200-M12

Author: r.pop
Content: Definitely looks like a photo eye to me. Likely a part present sensor.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yes, reflection sensor but one with a built-in reflector it seems.

Author: theunr
Content: Hey! I'm a student working on a downtime analysis for a production line and trying to create a Pareto analysis in Grafana of the biggest downtime causes, specifically summing the abort status duration per component (like in this visualization). I'm making good progress with the dashboard using ChatGPT without programming experience, but I've been stuck on this part for a while. Any tips or directions on how to achieve this in Grafana?

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Awesome stuff

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: You may have to program on node red or something. We have done this, but the problem we had was that you got an status that stopped the machine like starve and the operator took advantage of this(because he knew there was a problem upstring so the downtime was going to be a couple of minutes) and opened the door of the machine, which triggered another status and make the data no reliable without cleaning

Author: theunr
Content: Thanks for the suggestion, Mariano! üôåüèº  I see what you mean. In my case, I'm tracking downtime by calculating the time between the first "Aborted" status and the first "Operational (Execute)" status for each component. I understand that manual interventions like emergency stops can trigger multiple components to go into "Aborted" at the same time. To account for this, I'm considering using a query that detects simultaneous "Aborted" statuses across components and excludes these cases from the downtime analysis, as they likely represent manual interventions. Does this approach seem reasonable to you?

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: seems like and starting point

Content:
Any script that you write and save in the code-server IDE becomes available as a function call in ignition.

Write your code in python3 whatever libraries you want,
save,
use anywhere in Ignition as if it were part of the scripting library :)

Author: nirmal_9595
Content: I have worked with LoRaWAN extensive implementation across coal mines spread around 100 sq km. It is for an RTLS application we used Kerlink - Gateway to setup this mesh and its working well for close to 2 years now, i can share my knowledge and challenges we faced. It was a tuff terrain and LoRaWAN as a communication has major challenges in terms of bandwidth and handling data at scale with high transmission rate

Author: nirmal_9595
Content: Great, Also if would be great if you can recommend reliable sensor simulators that I can access for the demonstration

Author: brianpribe
Content: https://github.com/libremfg/PackML-MQTT-Simulator

Author: johanscheepers
Content:
Thank you for the offer, very kind of you.
We have rolled out LoRaWAN networks that cover entire cities.

The LoRa mesh is nice in that every node has a dual purpose, collecting sensor data and acting as a repeater. And then you only require one gateway into the cloud.

Thus if you require coverage in an area where the terrain or any other factor block coverage. You can just add a node to extend the coverage.

Author: nirmal_9595
Content: Great, We did exactly the same! Installed nodes wherever there was significant change in terrain, however had one gateway into the cloud.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Just replaced my Sindoh 1X printer (no longer supported) with a Bambu X1C and AMS 2 Pro filament system.  Wow.  Blown away.  Very high quality, great usability, excellent slicer - first impressions are extremely good.

Author: vatsalshah
Content: No H2D?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's just more stuff to break.  Only real benefit is dual nozzle for me.

Author: vatsalshah
Content: Yehh true. Dual Nozzle demos look pretty cool.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you're printing with two materials.  If you need more than that, you're still going to have to flush the nozzle and the feed tube.  The AMS 2 Pro coordinates pretty well with the printer, but it can waste a lot of filament if you're not thoughtful about how you sequence the colors/materials.

Author: vatsalshah
Content: That‚Äôs very interesting. Rather than changing nozzle,  the feeder changes the filament. Bambu P1S with AMS is on my list once I ‚Äúfinish‚Äù other projects üòÖ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'd recommend going up to the X1C.  Lots of niceties and upgrades that make it worth it.   Stuff goes wrong occasionally with 3D prints, and the X1C can detect them and stop the print before you waste a ton of filament or worse, damage the nozzle.  It also has built-in LIDAR for print calibration.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So, I have about a dozen prints on my Bambu X1C thus far (and I also set up the AMS 2 Pro multifilament feeder), and I am BLOWN AWAY by the print quality, overall experience, and supporting software.  10/10. Highly recommend.  I'll generally only be using Bambu filament even if it's a little more expensive thanks to the automatic RFID setup in the AMS.  So good.  So well designed.

Author: jeffeweizen
Content: I have heard a lot of great things about Bambu printers but have not looked into their AMS options until reading this thread, the 2 Pro looks awesome! Have you been using any of their support filaments with it?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I bought a spool of the support filament, but haven't tried it yet.  The "tree supports" that the Bambu has used for a couple of my prints worked really well - easy to remove with very little residue to clean up.  I haven't tried a multicolor/multimaterial print yet either.  I did get a couple print heads/hot ends so that I can experiment with their wood fiber and carbon fiber capabilities.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: One other very nice feature of the AMS 2 Pro is that it has a built-in filament dryer.

Author: jeffeweizen
Content: That is nice, that alone plus the ability to use separate support materials had me interested. I haven‚Äôt had a printer that could handle separate support material so I was curious how much easier that made it. Wood would be interesting to experiment with, in a previous role I printed some tooling with carbon fiber filament and it actually was noticeably more durable. Lots of possibilities with the Bambu that‚Äôs for sure

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Bambu makes a higher end model (H2D) that also does laser cutting and other cool stuff in addition to 3D printing.

Author: jeffeweizen
Content: Those are sweet, I had looked at the Snapmaker modular 3-in-1 (FDM, Laser, and CNC) last time I was in the market for a printer but those had reliability concerns at the time. Not sure what I‚Äôd do with a mini cnc but it‚Äôd be fun to have

Author: milanhurban
Content: I've had a Prusa MK4 for about two years now (meanwhile upgraded to MK4S) as the first 3D printer I personally own and am also very happy with it. Print quality is excellent, speed as well. Printed PLA, PETG, ASA and TPU so far, all with good results. I was looking at the Bambu machines while picking it but wasn't too sure about the company, they were very new at the time. On the other hand, I've been using various Prusa printers since the i3 days about 10 years ago, so knew them well. Plus building it from kit and making my own enclosure with lighting and HEPA/carbon filtering was a cool experience. All in all I don't regret my decision at all, but Bambu definitely have a good product as well.

Author: gaudi4
Content:
Hi everyone. I've been working on an IoT project at my summer internship to monitor air quality. 

I made custom ESP32 nodes (with displays) publish sensor data over MQTT with server-side TLS encryption to a Raspberry Pi hub. A Python script I wrote logs everything to a SQLite database, and Grafana is used for the real-time dashboard. It uses all FOSS tools and is all local.

I found the project really fun and I am super excited to become an IoT developer. I'd love to get advice from this community on how to make it more professional so I can tailor my future learning projects to be 'Industry 4.0 ready'.
 
What skills do you think are most important for me to learn?

Author: donpancoe
Content:
The Arduino Tre has been discontinued, but it had a Sitara AM335x processor so an Arduino port must exist for it
https://docs.arduino.cc/retired/boards/arduino-tre/

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I don't know what the ADAM-6700 uses, but I would check Analog Devices for their interface chips, which also include former Maxim and LT lines.
https://www.analog.com/en/product-category/interface-isolation.html

That said, when I have taken apart devices like AutomationDirect Productivity 1000 PLCs, they tend to use standard AD and DA converters for analog IO and MOSFETS with drivers for digital IO. The idea of specialized IO chips is that they are supposed to reduce size, parts count and design time while maintaining industrial levels of isolation, but they're probably going to be more expensive than standard parts.

Author: donpancoe
Content: I would further add that IO is the forgotten stepchild of IIoT. Everyone be like: put an application processor in it! Put Linux in it! Put Node-RED in it! But it still takes a lot of engineering grunt work to get hundreds of real-world IO into the digital realm. Trends like IO-Link or Single Pair Ethernet look promising, but those add significant cost in the world of load cells and Wheatstone bridges.

Author: svb0866
Content: Thank you for your reply. I am still learning. Thank you for pointing out Node-RED and the interface chips. I think this is what modern gateways and IO hardware use in the IIOT industry.

Author: svb0866
Content: Can Someone help me identify the PJ146M CP part? I think it is a TVS diode for 24 V clamp (Just a guess) LL51 is a Photomos. this is Used in DIgital Out of industrial IO PCB

Author: head_robotics_and_ai
Content:
These might be helpful  "
Based on the markings "PJ146M" and "CP" on the component, this appears to be a¬†PJ146M Schottky Barrier Diode."

And

 "multimeter diode test will tell you which it is:

Reads ~0.2‚Äì0.4V drop ‚Üí Schottky.

Reads open both ways until high-voltage applied ‚Üí TVS."

Author: svb0866
Content:
As Per ChatGPT Short answer: very unlikely. It looks like an SMC (DO-214AB) body with no cathode band, top-mark starts with PJ ‚Üí that strongly suggests a PanJit SMCJ-series TVS (often bidirectional), not a Schottky rectifier.

How to be sure in 60 seconds:

Look for a band: Schottky/rectifier parts almost always print a cathode band on the body and/or the PCB silkscreen has a diode arrow. Your part shows no band ‚Üí typical for bidirectional TVS.

Diode-mode test (DMM):

Schottky: ~0.15‚Äì0.35 V forward drop one way, open the other.

Bidirectional TVS: open in both directions at meter voltages (it won‚Äôt conduct until tens of volts).

Where it sits in the circuit:

Across a line to GND or across a pair near a connector/24 V rail = TVS placement.

In series with power into a buck/boost or after an inductor = rectifier/Schottky placement.

Given your earlier find (‚ÄúPJ146M‚Äù mapping to PanJit‚Äôs SMCJ code table) and the lack of polarity marking, call it a bidirectional TVS (SMCJxxCA-type) unless your meter says otherwise. If you tell me the rail it protects (e.g., 24 V), I‚Äôll suggest safe drop-in equivalents (e.g., SMCJ24CA / SMCJ30CA etc.).
